bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 19, 1875

div1.p: Reed reassures Emilie Lawrence of his devotion. He admits that she has great influence over him.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, August 19, 1875

opener.dateline:
Willet's Point,
New York Harbor,
August 19th 1875

div1.p:
I had
hoped to announce to you, in this
epistle, that the ring had been
forwarded, but, as yet, I have
not heard from Dr Torney, and
hence have not been to the city.
If I do not get a letter from
him, tomorrow, I shall go to
town & select a ring without
his assistance, although I
think that his taste would
yield a better result than
mine- I am aware that no
particular haste is required in
the matter; yet I dislike any
unnecessary delay. I blame my-
self for neglecting to take the
measure of your finger while
I was in Murfreesboro, in-
stead of trusting simply to my
judgement as to the required
size. If I had entertained the
thought that my appointment
would have been delayed as
long as it was, I should have
attended to the matter long
since- I merely say this, in
order that you may not think
that I have been, at all, in-
different.

You expressed the desire, in
your last letter, that I should
abandon my habit of writing
on Sunday- It was not, at
all, necessary that you should
add that it would please you
better. Your wish, my own dar-
ling, would have been all-suf-
ficient with me. To comply
with your requests is my great-
est delight- I thank my Maker
that I am betrothed to a lady
who has such an elavated
idea of the sacredness of the
Sabbath. To know that you
are striving to live the life
of a Christian brings me much
happiness; and nothing could
so influence me to walk
justly before God & man (a-
side from the consciousness of the
debt which I owe to Heaven)
as the knowledge that it would
meet with your wishes. Ah!
Emilie, darling, you do not
know what an influence you pos-
sess over my thoughts & actions.
You would scarcely believe
me, did I reveal to you the
extent of that influence. Oh!
the power of woman's influence
when the heart of man is brought
into subjection through love!
Her frown prostrates him in
the dust-; her smile lifts him
to Heaven! Ah! tell me of the
brilliant accomplishments of
man, & I will tell you of a
heart enchained! Tell me of
an effort that knows no relax-
ation, by day or night, and I will
tell you of the power of woman's
influence- She can degrade
him to the level of a brute;
She can elevate him to the
position of a god! How care-
ful should she be in the use of
of this great influence!

Yes, my darling, since you re-
quest it, I will no longer write
on Sunday, but on Monday; and
if need be, I will devote all the
day to my letter, since no one
has so just a claim on
my time as your sweet self-
Do you know, my precious E., that
I have been much distressed
in mind, since I received your
last letter? Since its reception,
not one moment have you
been absent from my thoughts.
That anything should have
occurred to grieve you, or to
cause you to distrust human
nature, gives me much pain.
Believe me, nothing but the
exigency of circumstances
prevents me from being at
your side, to offer myself
as a willing mark for all
the darts that may be cast
at you. Ah! my darling, no
sigh escapes from your breast
but moves a responsive chord
in my heart! Why should
you feel aught of sorrow, my
dear E., & I not be present to
share it with you! when I had
rather weep with you than
rejoice with the Kings of
Earth! Oh! that the day may
soon come when I will be
given the right to be a par-
taker of your griefs & joys;
when I may press you to
my heart & with mine own
hands wipe away your
tears! Did I say “tears”! no,
No, my sweet, there'll be no
tears then! “we'll live & love
so true, the sigh that rends
thy constant heart, will breaks
thy” Walter's “too”!

You say, “would that I could
tell you all; but no, I cannot.
Sometime in the future, it may
be revealed.” Why can you not
tell me? Can't you trust me, my
darling? I know you can. Will
you not tell me whether I am
interested, personally, in your
trouble? I may have miscon-
trued your words. If I have, no
harm has been done, & it has
given me an opportunity
to proffer you my heartfelt
sympathy. Will you permit
me to offer a supposition as
to the cause of your recent unhappi-
ness? Remember that I offer it as
the merest supposition- It may
cause you to laugh at my silly
solicitude -- perhaps, it may not-
It is, that some member of your
family has taken a decided
stand in opposition to our en-
gagement- I know not what
influence this might have with
you, my darling; (& yet I should never,
for a moment, doubt you.)- With
myself, it could have no possible
influence- It is far too late for
that! The time was when I would
have listened to any objections,
(& it would have become me so
to do.) but, at present, there is no
power on earth that could cause
me to change one “jot or tittle”!
And though your whole family
were arraigned against me, one
& all, it would only increase the
devotion of your
div1.closer:
fond & affectionate Walter-
P.S. Remember me very kindly
to your sister, Mrs Harrold-
W.
Don't think that I believe that
any one of your family is opposed
to me. I merely offered the sup-
position, for the purpose of
expressing myself on the subject.
W. R.
